This week is the [Docathon](https://bids.github.io/docathon/) at [BIDS](https://bids.berkeley.edu/) (a.k.a. that wonderful place that I spend all my time). 

A docathon is like a hackathon but is focused on developing material and tools for documentation. We have [loads of projects](https://bids.github.io/docathon/pages/projects/projects.html) signed up to receive some documentation-love and an impressive number of excited participants!



::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](img/docathon/docathon.jpg-large){fig-align='center'}
:::
:::




We kicked off the event with a series of tutorials for writing "good" documentation. I gave an R-specific tutorial where I discussed using devtools to both develop and document your package. I ended with a sneak peak into bookdown book-based documentation for complex packages. Skip ahead to 1:54:02 to hear my presentation! 

<center>
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ikT_xnTFHC0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
</center>

The materials for my tutorial can be found in this [github repo](https://github.com/rlbarter/R-documentation). Stay tuned for a more detailed blog post about writing documentation in R.
